admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation Loan Project will
            provide foreign exchange to finance critically needed
            imports, while supporting the government in the
            implementation of its ongoing stabilization and structural
            reform program (which will also be supported by an IMF
            Stand-By Arrangement that has been prepared in parallel). A
            policy framework of systematic and structural reforms has
            been developed with the assistance of the Bank in the
            following areas: enterprise reform (including
            privatization), pro-competition and anti-monopoly policies,
            financial sector reforms, establishment of a social safety
            net and strengthening economic management. Basic imports are
            urgently required to prevent further deterioration of the
            existing capital stock, to maintain essential services such
            as power, heating, transport and health services, and to
            generate a supply response to the new set of incentives in
            key productive sectors. The Rehabilitation Loan Project will
            finance the following components: (a) pre-identified imports
            in four key sectors (energy, agriculture, transport and
            health); (b) a small technical assistance component to
            support loan implementation and the government's
            structural reform program.
